dublin_core.description: An interactive MicroSim demonstrating how the Price-to-Earnings (P/E) ratio is calculated and used to evaluate company valuation. Students can adjust stock price and earnings per share to see real-time P/E calculations and compare against industry averages to assess overvaluation or undervaluation.

educational.topic: Valuation Metrics and Financial Performance Analysis
learning_objectives: Understand how P/E ratio is calculated from stock price and earnings per share
Apply P/E ratio analysis to evaluate whether a stock is overvalued or undervalued
Analyze how changes in price or earnings affect the P/E multiple
Evaluate the appropriateness of different P/E levels across industries
prerequisites: Understanding of stock prices and what they represent
Familiarity with earnings and profitability concepts
Awareness of companies operating in different industries
assessment_opportunities: Can students correctly calculate P/E given price and earnings?
Can they explain why P/E changes when price or earnings change?
Can they interpret whether a given P/E suggests overvaluation or undervaluation?
Can they compare valuations across different industries appropriately?

visualizations.description: Shows the P/E ratio formula and live calculation
Prominent display of calculated P/E ratio with color coding
visualizations.purpose: Provides immediate visual feedback on valuation level

visualizations.description: Horizontal bar chart comparing company P/E to industry average
Text label indicating overvalued, fairly valued, or undervalued status
visualizations.purpose: Helps students interpret the numerical P/E value

simulation_model.methodology: Real-time calculation of P/E ratio with comparative valuation analysis
assumptions: Valuation assessment is relative, not absolute
P/E ratios don't account for growth rates (PEG ratio would)
limitations: Does not consider growth rates (use PEG ratio for that)
Does not account for debt levels or financial leverage
Ignores cash flow and other financial metrics
Simplified industry categories don't capture sub-sector differences
No adjustment for one-time earnings events
Does not factor in dividend yields or payout ratios

pedagogical_context.instructional_strategy: Exploratory learning with scaffolded scenarios moving from simple to complex
pedagogical_context.cognitive_load: Medium - single metric focus but requires understanding of numerator/denominator relationship
learning_progression: Understand the P/E formula through direct manipulation
Observe how price and earnings independently affect P/E
Evaluate appropriateness of valuations in context
common_misconceptions: Higher P/E is always better (actually signals higher expectations and risk)
P/E works for all companies (meaningless for negative earnings)
P/E can be compared across all industries (sector context critical)
Low P/E always means good value (may signal fundamental problems)
